Drawing on thirty years of research, 
Goulson
 
has written an accessible, 
fascinating, and important book that 
examines the evidence of an alarming 
drop in insect numbers around the world. 
“If we lose the insects, then everything is 
going to collapse,” he warned in a recent 
interview in the
New York Times
—
beginning with humans’ food supply. The 
main cause of this decrease in insect 
populations is the indiscriminate use of 
chemical pesticides. ....What will happen 
when the bugs are all gone? 
Goulson
 
explores the intrinsic connection between 
climate change, nature, wildlife, and the 
shrinking biodiversity and analyzes the 
harmful impact for the earth and its 
inhabitants.

Taking action:
 
what can we do
 
to support 
bee populations?
By the end of this section of the course, you should be able to:
•
Identify possible actions that can benefit bee populations
•
Recognize that the actions needed for supporting wild bees 
may differ from those needed for supporting managed bees 
(ex: honey bees)
•
Learn to identify bee
-
washing practices
•
Decide on TWO actions YOU could enact in the coming 
year

Would you keep chickens

Example 2: “Oops” 
by General Mills

1.
Home Depot: In 2015, Home Depot faced criticism for selling 
plants treated with neonicotinoid pesticides, despite promoting 
themselves as being supportive of pollinators. This led to 
accusations of bee
-
washing, as the company was using pollinators as 
a marketing tool, while their practices were harmful to pollinator 
populations.
2.
Walmart: Walmart faced similar criticism in 2015 for selling 
neonicotinoid
-
treated plants, and for not adequately labeling them 
as such. This led to concerns about the impact of the pesticides on 
pollinators, and accusations of bee
-
washing.
3.
Shell: In 2018, Shell was criticized for promoting their support for 
pollinators, despite using neonicotinoid pesticides in their 
agriculture supply chain. This was seen as a form of bee
-
washing, as 
the company was using pollinators as a marketing tool, while their 
practices were harmful to pollinator populations.

What can YOU (college student at CU) do? 
-
Buy locally produced food(support local farmers)
-
buy products from local bee keepers (support local bees)
-
support organic agriculture or local farms that do not use pesticides or are pollinator friendly
-
Support local beekeepers and honey industry in upstate NY. 
-
Support a society that focuses on insect/pollinator conservation
-
Spread the word about best practices to farmers (techniques to mitigate pesticides, 
plant flower strips and bee
-
friendly corridors around some fields, etc.)
-
Spread the word about best practices in gardens (native plants Spring/summer/Fall, limit 
pesticides, provide habitats and water, etc.)
-
stop eating grain
-
fed beef entirely which is very environmentally damaging
-
Help with data collection on apps like 
iNaturalist

-
volunteer at community gardens (use native plants) to create a good habitat for bees
-
join the CU Honey bee club!

joining conservation groups or email lists to stay informed about issues for pollinators; donating
